generated_summary: Nastia Liukin, a former Olympic gold medalist and "Dancing With the Stars" contestant, has started her own business, Shine Agency, and in doing so, has criticized her former agents, saying they never got her deals she could be "passionate about." One of her former agents, Evan Morgenstein, has responded, saying that Liukin's comments are a "slap in the face" and that he scored her numerous lucrative deals, including JCPenney and Wheaties, during the time he represented her from 2007 to 2012. Morgenstein believes that Liukin thinks she can do better on her own, but he is skeptical of her abilities, comparing her ambition to that of sports agent Scott Boras. Liukin has not responded to requests for comment.

Savers who did not panic during the 2009 market bottom have benefited from the long-term growth of stocks, which have outperformed money market funds and bonds. The Obama administration's new standards to reduce pollution from car exhaust may increase gas prices, with the oil industry claiming up to 9 cents per gallon and the EPA disputing this estimate. A federal appeals court has ruled that the EPA can halt construction projects at power plants if they believe the companies did not properly calculate air pollution increases. Amazon has purchased Goodreads, a social network and book recommendation platform with 16 million members.

original_summary: For Stephen Curry, basketball in hands is masterpiece theater  In the quiet of summer, at a gym in his hometown of Charlotte, N.C., Stephen Curry works on his ballhandling.  Curry long ago gained acclaim as one of the NBA’s best outside shooters, but the roots of his captivating game rest in his extraordinary ballhandling.    Or flash back to Dec. 2, in the waning seconds against the Magic.  Today’s top ballhandlers — Kyrie Irving, Chris Paul and Curry are widely regarded as the best in the NBA — extend a long legacy of artistry with the ball.  Just picture Bob Cousy literally dribbling circles around opponents to run out the clock on another Celtics championship.  Or Pete Maravich  going behind his back and through his legs, then making a clever pass as a teammate streaks to the basket.  Isiah Thomas and Steve Nash created offense through sweet ballhandling, as did Tim Hardaway and Allen Iverson with their lethal crossover moves.  [...] no conversation about the art of dribbling is complete without a nod to the playground legends of New York City, most notably God Shammgod, Rafer “Skip to My Lou” Alston and Kenny Anderson.  All three played AAU ball for Vincent Smith, the older brother of former NBA point guard Kenny Smith, now a TNT analyst.  Alston, in many ways, sparked the And1 phenomenon of the late 1990s, spreading the gospel about fancy, street-ball dribbling moves through a traveling basketball exhibition.  Warriors backup point guard Shaun Livingston, born and raised in Peoria, Ill., also was shaped by the “And1 generation,” as he put it.  The art of dribbling, as Curry sees it, starts with hand quickness and hand-eye coordination.  Curry met Payne through fellow NBA player Gerald Henderson during the 2011 lockout.  Payne seeks to improve Curry’s floor vision by training him in this “game state of mind” as much as possible.  Then-assistant coach Stephen Silas worked with Curry and Anthony Morrow, among other young players, on basic two-ball dribbling and passing drills.  “Steph has such high confidence in every aspect of his game, but especially his ballhandling,” said Silas, now a Hornets assistant.  [...] this includes more than Curry planting himself at the three-point line and letting it fly.  Ron Kroichick is a San Francisco Chronicle staff writer.
generated_summary: Stephen Curry, the point guard for the Golden State Warriors, is known for his exceptional ballhandling skills, which set him apart from other players in the NBA. He has a unique ability to dribble the ball with precision and speed, making it an integral part of his game. Curry's ballhandling skills are rooted in his childhood, where he spent hours dribbling in idle moments and honed his skills through training with personal trainer Brandon Payne. Payne's training methods, which include ankle-strengthening exercises, weighted basketballs, and reaction drills, have helped Curry develop hand quickness and coordination. Curry's ballhandling skills are so exceptional that he can dribble through congested spaces, create shots for himself and his teammates, and leave defenders stumbling. His ability to dribble and shoot has made him nearly unguardable, and he is widely regarded as one of the best ballhandlers in the NBA.

guard for the Golden State Warriors,

original_summary: South Korean prosecutors have indicted the local subsidiary of ride-share service Uber for violating a law governing public transport.
generated_summary: Uber's South Korean subsidiary and CEO Travis Kalanick have been indicted by Seoul prosecutors for violating a law that prohibits unlicensed individuals or firms from providing transportation services. The company charges fees to connect passengers and drivers through its apps, but has faced regulatory issues worldwide due to its relatively new business model. The indictment does not include any arrests, and the maximum penalty is a fine of $18,121 or a two-year prison sentence. The Seoul city legislature recently passed a measure to fine unregistered Uber drivers and offer rewards for reporting them.

original_summary: New research suggests that for the average person, decoding your own DNA may not turn out to be a really useful crystal ball for future health.
generated_summary: A recent study published in the journal Science Translational Medicine suggests that genome mapping may not be a useful tool for predicting future health risks for the average person. The study, conducted by researchers at Johns Hopkins University, found that while genome mapping can identify some genetic mutations that increase the risk of certain diseases, many common diseases are influenced by lifestyle and environment, making it difficult to accurately predict an individual's risk. Additionally, the study found that a negative test result for most diseases does not mean an individual is not at risk, as many diseases can still develop due to mutations that occur throughout a person's life. The study's senior author, Dr. Bert Vogelstein, noted that genome mapping can still be beneficial for customizing care for certain individuals, such as children with undiagnosed illnesses. Dr. James Lupski of Baylor College of Medicine also emphasized the potential benefits of genome mapping, including helping parents decide whether to have another child if a genetic disorder is detected.

original_summary: The social networking site is making it easier for people who express suicidal thoughts on the social networking site to get help.
generated_summary: Facebook is launching a new service to help people who express suicidal thoughts on the platform get immediate help. The service allows users to instantly connect with a crisis counselor through Facebook's chat messaging system. This new tool is aimed at improving safety on the site and is the latest addition to Facebook's efforts to address bullying, offensive content, and fake profiles. The service is designed to get people in distress into the right help as soon as possible and is inspired by the fact that nearly 100 Americans die by suicide every day. The new service goes a step further than previous efforts by enabling an instant chat session that experts say can make a difference in reducing suicidal thinking. If a friend spots a suicidal thought on someone's page, they can report it to Facebook, which will then send an email to the person encouraging them to call a hotline or click on a link to begin a confidential chat. The Lifeline currently responds to dozens of users on Facebook each day, and crisis center workers will be available 24/7 to respond to users selecting the chat option.

original_summary: Americans aren't angry about health-care costs. They're angry about the small fraction of health-care costs they directly pay.
generated_summary:
Many Americans believe that healthcare costs are rising, but in reality, the cost of healthcare has been slowing down. According to a survey by the Kaiser Family Foundation, most Americans think healthcare costs are rising faster than normal, but in reality, the cost of healthcare has been growing at a historically slow rate. Even House Speaker John Boehner has mistakenly blamed the Affordable Care Act for causing premiums to soar. However, the law is actually causing a slowdown in premiums.

One reason for the misconception is that employees are seeing deductibles rise, which makes healthcare feel more expensive even though costs are slowing down for employers. The cost control efforts in the Affordable Care Act, such as higher deductibles and tighter networks, may also contribute to this misconception.

Polls show that Americans want to see healthcare costs brought down, but this may not be the same thing as seeing total healthcare costs fall. Americans are angry about the small fraction of healthcare costs they directly pay, rather than the overall cost of healthcare.

The Navy is concerned about the embarrassment of having mechanical breakdowns in front of its closest ally, the US Navy.

original_summary: Live coverage as German politician reveals content of letter from NSA whistleblower to German chancellor whose phone he revealed had been monitored by the US for a decade • New readers start here • What do the NSA Files mean for you? • Read a summary of today's key events
generated_summary:
The NSA controversy continues to make headlines around the world, with new developments and reactions emerging daily. In the US, Secretary of State John Kerry acknowledged that some surveillance activities have gone too far and promised a thorough review and changes to ensure that certain practices end altogether. The director of the NSA, General Keith Alexander, blamed US diplomats for requests to place foreign leaders under surveillance. The Senate intelligence committee approved a bill that places cosmetic restrictions on the NSA's domestic surveillance program, while technology giants called for substantial reforms to the US government's surveillance programs.

In other countries, there are also reactions and developments related to the NSA's activities. In Indonesia, the foreign minister expressed concern over Australia's spying on the region at the behest of the US, and sought clarification from his Australian counterpart. In Britain, MI5's director general, Andrew Parker, was criticized for suggesting that the Guardian's reporting of the National Security Agency files had provided a gift to terrorists. Edward Snowden may be invited to Germany as a witness against the US National Security Agency, as action is underway in the Bundestag to commission a parliamentary investigation into US intelligence service spying.

Overall, the debate about privacy in the digital age continues to be a major concern globally, with many calling for greater transparency and accountability from governments and intelligence agencies.

original_summary: The phone caught fire while she was watching a movie.
generated_summary: An Alaska Airlines flight from Bellingham, Washington, to Hawaii encountered a frightening situation when a passenger's iPhone 6 caught fire during the flight. Anna Crail was watching a movie on her phone when it suddenly burst into flames, causing panic among the 163 passengers onboard. The crew quickly extinguished the flames, but the incident has raised concerns about the safety of cell phones on planes. Aviation expert John Nance believes that this incident may lead to stricter regulations regarding cell phones on flights.

original_summary: Byron Scott and Jason Kidd likely won’t be golfing together anytime soon. The two coaches met in a match-up between the Lakers and Bucks.
generated_summary: Los Angeles Lakers coach Byron Scott and Milwaukee Bucks coach Jason Kidd have a tense history, which was evident when Scott called Kidd an "a--hole" before their teams faced off on Wednesday. Scott and Kidd have a history that dates back to their time together on the New Jersey Nets, where Scott was the coach and Kidd was his point guard. Scott's dislike for Kidd reportedly stems from Kidd's involvement in Scott's firing in 2004. Kidd responded to Scott's comment by downplaying it, but Scott made it clear that their relationship is not friendly, describing it as "cordial" at best. Scott also criticized Kidd for intentionally spilling a soda on the court last season to buy his team more time, which resulted in a $50,000 fine.

The author suggests that FIFA should reconsider the rule that amounts to triple jeopardy for defenders in situations like Schmelzer's, where a mistake by the referee can result in a penalty, red card, and automatic one-match ban.

original_summary: Taliban  insurgents shot down a U.S. Chinook helicopter early Saturday, killing 31 American troops and seven Afghans aboard, U.S. and Afghan officials said. It was the war's greatest single-incident loss of military lives.
generated_summary: A US Chinook helicopter was shot down by insurgents in Afghanistan, killing 31 American troops and 7 Afghans. The casualties included members of SEAL Team Six, the special operations unit that carried out the raid that killed Osama bin Laden. The helicopter was brought down by a rocket-propelled grenade moments after takeoff. The incident occurred in Wardak province, west of Kabul, during a firefight that left eight insurgents dead. The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack, saying it was in response to an imminent night raid in the district. The crash site has been cordoned off and recovery efforts are underway. The incident is a major blow to the close-knit and secretive SEAL Team Six, and represents a setback for Western efforts to establish calm in Afghanistan as forces begin drawing down.
matched_patterns: DT NN VBZ DT JJ NN

original_summary: Trial has been delayed again for two Americans detained in Iran for more than 21 months after being detained during a hiking trek along the Iran-Iraq border. According to their lawyer, neither Shane Bauer, a freelance journalist who has contributed...
generated_summary: The trial of two American hikers, Shane Bauer and Joshua Fattal, detained in Iran for over 21 months on security charges, has been delayed again. The hikers were not brought to the courtroom for the scheduled hearing, and no new trial date was announced. The hikers' lawyer submitted a complaint to the court, but authorities offered no explanation for the delay. The hikers are being held in Tehran's Evin Prison and face charges of espionage and trespassing. Diplomats and journalists waited for over four hours outside the court, but an official from the Swiss Embassy, which represents U.S. interests in Iran, said a request to attend any court session had been rejected. Iran has rejected any proposed exchange of prisoners, despite demanding the release of alleged arms smugglers held in U.S. prisons.

original_summary: Who's to argue with a guy who has 19 gold medals and believes in cupping?
generated_summary: Many Olympic swimmers, including Michael Phelps, have been using a technique called cupping to help with sore and injured muscles. Cupping involves attaching suction cups to the skin to pull blood into the area and promote healing. The technique leaves round bruises on the skin, which have been visible on several swimmers during competition. While some experts are skeptical of its effectiveness, many swimmers swear by it and believe it helps them recover faster. Cupping is not limited to swimmers, as other athletes, such as gymnast Alexander Naddour, have also used the technique.

original_summary: Former Penn State assistant football coach Jerry Sandusky's trial on 52 criminal counts begins Monday.
generated_summary: Jerry Sandusky, a former Penn State assistant football coach, is on trial for 52 criminal counts of child sexual abuse. The trial begins Monday and is expected to last a few weeks. In addition to the trial, several other investigations are underway, including a state grand jury, federal prosecutors, Penn State's own investigation, and civil litigators. Sandusky has denied the allegations, which include charges that he attacked children inside Penn State football team showers and at his own home in State College.

original_summary: A KEY witness in the murder trial of millionaire businessman Shiren Dewani was found hanged at home. Leopold Leisser, 45, who is a former prostitute, was found by a friend in his flat in Birmingham…
generated_summary: Leopold Leisser, a former prostitute and key witness in the murder trial of millionaire businessman Shiren Dewani, was found dead in his Birmingham flat in September. A postmortem revealed that he died from hanging, and a coroner recorded a verdict of suicide. Leisser had been suffering from stress due to the 2014 court case, in which he testified that Dewani paid him for sex sessions. Leisser's family and the family of Anni Dewani, the victim, had met with him during the trial and thanked him for his courage in testifying. Leisser's suicide has been described as a tragic loss, and his family and friends have expressed their sadness at his death.

original_summary: It can be a reality check around just how much an employer impacts your life, which can often lead to a 'crisis of confidence.'
generated_summary: There are three main ways that people can be terminated from their jobs: fired for poor performance, laid off as part of a reduction in force (RIF), or let go as part of a restructuring. Regardless of the reason, it's important to handle the situation professionally and quickly move on to find a new job. Employers want to see that you can learn and grow from negative experiences, so it's important to be able to effectively explain what happened and what you've learned from it. Severance pay may be offered in some cases, but it's important to also be mindful of the reference check policy and make sure you can articulate what happened properly. The best way to move forward is to focus on finding a new, better-fit job as quickly as possible.

original_summary: It was casual court day for Chris Brown , who got high marks for his community service over the whole Rihanna thing. Brown and his lawyer, Mark Geragos ,…
generated_summary: Chris Brown appeared in court for a progress hearing regarding his community service and domestic violence classes stemming from his assault on Rihanna. Brown's lawyer presented proof that he had completed 32 days of hard labor in Virginia and attended 17 out of the required 52 domestic violence classes. The judge was satisfied with Brown's progress and allowed him to travel out of the country for concerts from May 18 to June 27, provided he gets permission from her in advance. Brown is scheduled to return to court on May 11 for the next progress hearing.

* Ministry of Supply: A discussion on the future of wearable technology and its impact on the fashion industry, held at Ministry of Supply, 299 Newbury St., Boston, from 6 to 8 p.m. on Thursday. Free to attend.

The move is met with sadness and frustration from fans and city officials, who feel that the Maloofs have not done enough to keep the team in Sacramento.

original_summary: He's not really into the Twitter.
generated_summary: Lester Holt, the moderator of the first presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump, is a registered Republican, despite Trump's claims that he is a Democrat. Holt, who is black, has been a journalist for over 30 years and has worked for NBC News since 2000. He has been a anchor of "NBC Nightly News" since 2015. Holt's selection as moderator is significant, as he is the first black journalist to moderate a general election presidential debate since 1992. However, his background is not expected to influence his questioning, as he is a journalist first and foremost. Holt has a reputation for being fair and professional, and he has shown a willingness to ask tough questions, as demonstrated in a previous Democratic debate where he asked Hillary Clinton about her reset button policy with Russia. Holt is not very active on social media, and he has not tweeted in almost a month. He has received honorary doctorates from Cal State Sacramento and Pepperdine University.

original_summary: Most of public supports extending benefits to same-sex marriages but Supreme Court ruling will set the course.
generated_summary: A pending Supreme Court decision on the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) could have significant implications for the extension of federal employee benefits to same-sex spouses. A recent Gallup poll found that a majority of Americans (54%) support granting these benefits, while 39% are opposed and 7% have no opinion. The poll found that 73% of Democrats and 52% of independents support extending benefits, but only 38% of Republicans do. If DOMA is struck down, it is unclear how the ruling will be applied and what benefits will be extended to same-sex spouses. The Obama administration has previously extended some benefits to same-sex couples who meet certain standards for domestic partnership, but these benefits are limited and less valuable than those available to opposite-sex spouses. Proposals to grant the full range of federal employment benefits to same-sex domestic partners have made little progress in Congress. The Supreme Court's decision could potentially pave the way for the extension of full benefits to same-sex spouses, but it is uncertain how the decision will be applied and what benefits will be extended.
